description: FITCHBURG- With the state reopening the economy and businesses gearing up to resume operations, the city formed its new Reopening Fitchburg Task Force to lend a hand during the transition. The group includes both business owners and city personnel, he said, and will be chaired by Community Development Executive Director Tom Skwierawski and overseen by Public...
text:
FITCHBURG - With the state reopening the economy and businesses gearing up to
resume operations, the city formed its new Reopening Fitchburg Task Force to
lend a hand during the transition.

During a press conference on Friday, Mayor Stephen DiNatale said he put the
task force together to help business owners.

"This task force will assist the business sector with technical support and
provide guidance with sector-specific reopening plans," DiNatale said.

The group includes both business owners and city personnel, he said, and will
be chaired by Community Development Executive Director Tom Skwierawski and
overseen by Public Health Director Steve Curry.

A subcommittee was also formed to establish processes and protocols for
reopening all municipal buildings.

According to the mayor, the committee will be tasked with establishing a
standard control plan and return to work policy that follows Gov. Charlie
Baker's directives, as well as those of the Board of Health.

"Once these standards are created, the committee will work with department
heads to gain input, as well as to address department specific requirements,"
DiNatale said. "As these plans are formulated, we will be able to determine
and provide specifics, as well as a timeline for implementation."

Residents can visit the city's COVID-19 resource page for the full list of
people serving on the committees.

The mayor also gave an update regarding the virus during his briefing, saying
that 712 people had tested positive for the virus as of Friday.

There have been 52 deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the city.

However, DiNatale noted, this is the number of individuals who have died and
were positive for the virus, but the death records may vary as the virus may
not be the official cause of death.

DiNatale encouraged residents to use the state's test site locator map, at
[mass.gov](http://mass.gov), to find testing facilities nearby.

title: Fitchburg establishes reopening task force
html:
FITCHBURG - With the state reopening the economy and businesses gearing up to resume operations, the city formed its new Reopening Fitchburg Task Force to lend a hand during the transition.

During a press conference on Friday, Mayor Stephen DiNatale said he put the task force together to help business owners.

"This task force will assist the business sector with technical support and provide guidance with sector-specific reopening plans," DiNatale said.

The group includes both business owners and city personnel, he said, and will be chaired by Community Development Executive Director Tom Skwierawski and overseen by Public Health Director Steve Curry.

A subcommittee was also formed to establish processes and protocols for reopening all municipal buildings.

According to the mayor, the committee will be tasked with establishing a standard control plan and return to work policy that follows Gov. Charlie Baker's directives, as well as those of the Board of Health.

"Once these standards are created, the committee will work with department heads to gain input, as well as to address department specific requirements," DiNatale said. "As these plans are formulated, we will be able to determine and provide specifics, as well as a timeline for implementation."

Residents can visit the city's COVID-19 resource page for the full list of people serving on the committees.

The mayor also gave an update regarding the virus during his briefing, saying that 712 people had tested positive for the virus as of Friday.

There have been 52 deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the city.

However, DiNatale noted, this is the number of individuals who have died and were positive for the virus, but the death records may vary as the virus may not be the official cause of death.

DiNatale encouraged residents to use the state's test site locator map, at mass.gov, to find testing facilities nearby.
